title: Flat Roof Snow Load Calculation
problem: Determine the design flat roof snow load for an office building located in Denver, Colorado. The building has a flat roof at an elevation of 5,500 feet. The roof is partially exposed, and the building is located in Terrain Category B. The building has a Risk Category II classification. The ground snow load from ASCE 7-16 Figure 7.2-1 is pg = 18 psf.
required: Calculate the design flat roof snow load pf.

solution_steps.title: Determine Exposure Factor Ce
solution_steps.content: From ASCE 7-16 Table 7.3-1, for Terrain Category B and partially exposed roof: Ce = 1.0

solution_steps.title: Determine Thermal Factor Ct
solution_steps.content: From ASCE 7-16 Table 7.3-2, for heated structure (typical office building): Ct = 1.0

solution_steps.title: Determine Importance Factor Is
solution_steps.content: From ASCE 7-16 Table 1.5-2, for Risk Category II: Is = 1.0

solution_steps.title: Calculate Flat Roof Snow Load
solution_steps.content: Using ASCE 7-16 Equation 7.3-1: pf = 0.7 × Ce × Ct × Is × pg. pf = 0.7 × 1.0 × 1.0 × 1.0 × 18 = 12.6 psf

solution_steps.title: Check Minimum Snow Load
solution_steps.content: Per ASCE 7-16 Section 7.3.4, the minimum snow load for low-slope roofs (θ ≤ 15°): pf(min) = Is × pg for pg ≤ 20 psf. pf(min) = 1.0 × 18 = 18 psf. Also check: pf(min) = Is × 20 for pg > 20 psf. Since pf = 12.6 psf < pf(min) = 18 psf, use pf = 18 psf.

final_answer: The design flat roof snow load is pf = 18 psf (minimum snow load governs over the calculated value of 12.6 psf). This value should be used for the uniform snow load case.

title: Sloped Roof Snow Load
problem: Calculate the sloped roof snow load for a warehouse building with a gable roof having a slope of 4:12 (18.4°). The building is located in Chicago, Illinois, with a ground snow load of pg = 25 psf. The roof is unobstructed, slippery (metal roofing), and the building is unheated. Terrain Category C applies, and the roof is fully exposed.
required: Calculate the sloped roof snow load ps.

solution_steps.title: Determine Exposure and Thermal Factors
solution_steps.content: From ASCE 7-16 Table 7.3-1, for Terrain Category C and fully exposed roof: Ce = 0.9. From ASCE 7-16 Table 7.3-2, for unheated structure: Ct = 1.2. From ASCE 7-16 Table 1.5-2, for Risk Category II: Is = 1.0

solution_steps.title: Calculate Flat Roof Snow Load
solution_steps.content: pf = 0.7 × Ce × Ct × Is × pg = 0.7 × 0.9 × 1.2 × 1.0 × 25 = 18.9 psf. Check minimum: pf(min) = Is × pg = 25 psf for pg ≤ 20 psf. Since pg = 25 psf > 20 psf, pf(min) = Is × 20 = 20 psf. Use pf = 20 psf.

solution_steps.title: Determine Slope Factor Cs
solution_steps.content: From ASCE 7-16 Figure 7.4-1(a) for slippery surfaces with unobstructed roofs. For unheated building (Ct = 1.2) and slippery surface: The roof is considered 'cold' and 'slippery'. For θ = 18.4° and Ct = 1.2: Cs = 1.0 for θ ≤ 15° (warm roofs) or θ ≤ 30° (unheated). Actually, from Figure 7.4-1, for Ct > 1.0 (unheated), Cs = 1.0 for all slopes up to approximately 37.5°. Therefore: Cs = 1.0

solution_steps.title: Calculate Sloped Roof Snow Load
solution_steps.content: Using ASCE 7-16 Equation 7.4-1: ps = Cs × pf = 1.0 × 20 = 20 psf

solution_steps.title: Check if Snow Slides Off
solution_steps.content: For slippery surfaces, snow may slide off if the roof slope is steep enough. However, for unheated buildings, the critical slope for sliding is approximately 45°, which is higher than 18.4°. Therefore, full snow load should be considered.

final_answer: The sloped roof snow load is ps = 20 psf. The minimum flat roof snow load governs, and the slope factor Cs = 1.0 for an unheated building with a slippery surface at 18.4° slope. Additional checks for unbalanced snow loads and drifts may be required.

title: Snow Load Calculation for Gable Roof
problem: A commercial building in Syracuse, New York, has a gable roof with a slope of 6:12 (26.6°). The building is heated and has a Risk Category II classification. The roof is 80 ft wide and 120 ft long. The ground snow load $p_g$ is 40 psf. The building is located in an area with terrain Category B and is fully exposed with no obstructions. The roof is not shielded by trees or other buildings. Determine the balanced snow load and the unbalanced snow load for the leeward side of the roof. The roof has no sliding snow concerns and no obstructions at the eaves.
given: Ground snow load, $p_g = 40$ psf (from Figure 7.2-1 or local data)
Building dimensions: width = 80 ft (horizontal projection), length = 120 ft
Terrain Category B, Fully exposed roof (Table 7.3-1, Surface Roughness B, Fully Exposed)
No obstructions at eaves, no sliding snow
required: Calculate the unbalanced snow load on the leeward side (psf).

solution_steps.title: Determine Exposure Factor $C_e$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Table 7.3-1, for Terrain Category B and Fully Exposed roof:
$$C_e = 0.9$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Thermal Factor $C_t$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Table 7.3-2, for Heated building:
$$C_t = 1.0$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Importance Factor $I_s$
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Table 1.5-2, for Risk Category II:
$$I_s = 1.0$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Flat Roof Snow Load $p_f$
solution_steps.content:
ASCE 7-16 Equation 7.3-1:
$$p_f = 0.7 C_e C_t I_s p_g$$
$$p_f = 0.7 \times 0.9 \times 1.0 \times 1.0 \times 40$$
$$p_f = 0.7 \times 0.9 \times 40 = 0.63 \times 40 = 25.2 \text{ psf}$$

Check minimum $p_f$ per Section 7.3.4:
For $p_g \le 20$ psf? No, $p_g = 40$ psf > 20 psf, so no minimum increase needed.
Also check $p_f \ge p_g I_s = 40$ psf? No, $p_f = 25.2$ psf < 40 psf, so $p_f = 25.2$ psf governs.

solution_steps.title: Apply Slope Factor for Balanced Snow Load
solution_steps.content:
From ASCE 7-16 Section 7.4, for warm roofs ($C_t = 1.0$) and $\theta = 26.6°$:

First, find the thermal factor threshold:
For $C_t = 1.0$, the threshold slope is $\theta = 30°$ per Figure 7.4-1(b).
Since $\theta = 26.6° < 30°$, slope factor $C_s = 1.0$.

Balanced snow load:
$$p_s = C_s p_f = 1.0 \times 25.2 = 25.2 \text{ psf}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Unbalanced Snow Load Parameters
solution_steps.content:
For gable roofs with $\theta > 15°$, unbalanced loads must be considered per Section 7.6.1.

First, determine $p_g = 40$ psf, $\theta = 26.6°$.

From Figure 7.6-2, for $\theta = 26.6°$:
- Windward side load = $0.3 p_s = 0.3 \times 25.2 = 7.56$ psf
- Leeward side load = $p_s \times (1.5 \text{ to } 3.0)$ depending on slope.

For $\theta = 26.6°$, the factor for leeward side from the chart is approximately $1.9 p_s$.

More precisely, ASCE 7-16 Section 7.6.1 provides that the leeward side load shall be determined from Figure 7.6-2. For $\theta = 26.6°$, reading the curve:
At $\theta = 20°$, factor = $1.5$
At $\theta = 30°$, factor = $2.5$ (for $p_g > 20$ psf)
Interpolating for $\theta = 26.6°$:
$$Factor = 1.5 + \frac{26.6 - 20}{30 - 20} \times (2.5 - 1.5) = 1.5 + 0.66 \times 1.0 = 2.16$$

Leeward unbalanced load:
$$p_{unbal,lee} = 2.16 \times p_s = 2.16 \times 25.2 = 54.4 \text{ psf}$$

solution_steps.title: Determine Load Distribution
solution_steps.content:
Per Section 7.6.1, the unbalanced load on the leeward side varies linearly from the ridge to the eave. The load at the ridge is $p_s$ and at the eave is $p_{unbal,lee}$. The windward side is $0.3 p_s$ uniformly.

For design, the maximum leeward load at the eave is $54.4$ psf.

final_answer: The balanced snow load is $25.2$ psf. The unbalanced snow load on the leeward side at the eave is $54.4$ psf.
